original_proof:
Replacing $a$ by $a-b$ in \eqref{eq:1.1.3} yields
$$
|a|\le|a-b|+|b|,
$$
so
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.6}
|a-b|\ge|a|-|b|.
\end{equation}
Interchanging $a$ and $b$ here yields
$$
|b-a|\ge|b|-|a|,
$$
which is equivalent to
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.7}
|a-b|\ge|b|-|a|,
\end{equation}
since $|b-a|=|a-b|$. Since
$$
\big||a|-|b|\big|=
\left\{\casespace\begin{array}{l} |a|-|b|\mbox{\quad if \quad} |a|>|b|,\\[2\jot]
 |b|-|a|\mbox{\quad if \quad} |b|>|a|,
\end{array}\right.
$$
\eqref{eq:1.1.6} and \eqref{eq:1.1.7} imply \eqref{eq:1.1.4}. Replacing
$b$ by $-b$  in \eqref{eq:1.1.4} yields \eqref{eq:1.1.5}, since
$|-b|=|b|$.

```lean4
import Mathlib
import Aesop

set_option maxHeartbeats 0

open BigOperators Real Nat Topology Rat Filter

/-
Informal Problem Statement:
If $a$ and $b$ are any two real numbers, then
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.4}
|a-b|\ge\big||a|-|b|\big|
\end{equation}
and
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.5}
|a+b|\ge\big||a|-|b|\big|.
\end{equation}

Informal Proof:
Replacing $a$ by $a-b$ in \eqref{eq:1.1.3} yields
$$
|a|\le|a-b|+|b|,
$$
so
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.6}
|a-b|\ge|a|-|b|.
\end{equation}
Interchanging $a$ and $b$ here yields
$$
|b-a|\ge|b|-|a|,
$$
which is equivalent to
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.7}
|a-b|\ge|b|-|a|,
\end{equation}
since $|b-a|=|a-b|$. Since
$$
\big||a|-|b|\big|=
\left\{\casespace\begin{array}{l} |a|-|b|\mbox{\quad if \quad} |a|>|b|,\\[2\jot]
 |b|-|a|\mbox{\quad if \quad} |b|>|a|,
\end{array}\right.
$$
\eqref{eq:1.1.6} and \eqref{eq.1.1.7} imply \eqref{eq.1.1.4}. Replacing
$b$ by $-b$  in \eqref{eq.1.1.4} yields \eqref{eq.1.1.5}, since
$|-b|=|b|$.
-/

-- Theorem statement for |a-b| >= ||a|-|b||
theorem abs_sub_abs_le_abs_sub {a b : ℝ} : |a - b| ≥ ||a| - |b|| := by
  -- The informal proof relies on the triangle inequality: |x+y| <= |x|+|y|.
  -- We'll use the reverse triangle inequality in the form | |x| - |y| | <= |x-y|.

  -- Step 1: Prove |a-b| >= |a|-|b|
  -- The informal proof uses |x| <= |x-y|+|y| from |x| = |(x-y)+y| <= |x-y|+|y|.
  -- Let x = a and y = b. Then |a| <= |a-b| + |b|.
  -- Rearranging gives |a-b| >= |a| - |b|.
  have h1 : |a - b| ≥ |a| - |b| := by
    -- Triangle inequality: |x+y| <= |x|+|y|
    -- Let x = a - b, y = b. Then |(a-b)+b| <= |a-b| + |b|, which is |a| <= |a-b| + |b|.
    -- Rearrange to get |a-b| >= |a| - |b|.
    nth_rewrite 1 [← sub_add_cancel a b] -- Rewrite a as (a-b)+b
    exact le_sub_right_of_add_le (abs_add _ _)

  -- Step 2: Prove |a-b| >= |b|-|a|
  -- Interchanging a and b in the previous inequality: |b-a| >= |b|-|a|.
  -- Since |b-a| = |a-b|, we get |a-b| >= |b|-|a|.
  have h2 : |a - b| ≥ |b| - |a| := by
    rw [abs_sub_comm] -- |b-a| = |a-b|
    -- Apply the same logic as h1 for b and a.
    nth_rewrite 1 [← sub_add_cancel b a]
    exact le_sub_right_of_add_le (abs_add _ _)

  -- Step 3: Combine h1 and h2 to prove |a-b| >= ||a|-|b||.
  -- We know that |x| = max(x, -x).
  -- So, ||a|-|b|| = max(|a|-|b|, -(|a|-|b|)) = max(|a|-|b|, |b|-|a|).
  -- We need to show that |a-b| is greater than or equal to both |a|-|b| and |b|-|a|.
  exact abs_sub_abs_le_abs_sub_of_le h1 h2

-- Theorem statement for |a+b| >= ||a|-|b||
theorem abs_add_abs_le_abs_sub {a b : ℝ} : |a + b| ≥ ||a| - |b|| := by
  -- Replace b by -b in the first theorem: |a-(-b)| >= ||a|-|-b||
  -- This simplifies to |a+b| >= ||a|-|b||, since |-b| = |b|.
  have h_temp := abs_sub_abs_le_abs_sub (b := -b)
  rw [sub_neg_eq_add, abs_neg] at h_temp
  exact h_temp
```

import Mathlib
import Aesop

set_option maxHeartbeats 0

open BigOperators Real Nat Topology Rat Filter

/-
Informal Problem Statement:
If $a$ and $b$ are any two real numbers, then
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.4}
|a-b|\ge\big||a|-|b|\big|
\end{equation}
and
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.5}
|a+b|\ge\big||a|-|b|\big|.
\end{equation}

Informal Proof:
Replacing $a$ by $a-b$ in \eqref{eq:1.1.3} yields
$$
|a|\le|a-b|+|b|,
$$
so
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.6}
|a-b|\ge|a|-|b|.
\end{equation}
Interchanging $a$ and $b$ here yields
$$
|b-a|\ge|b|-|a|,
$$
which is equivalent to
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.7}
|a-b|\ge|b|-|a|,
\end{equation}
since $|b-a|=|a-b|$. Since
$$
\big||a|-|b|\big|=
\left\{\casespace\begin{array}{l} |a|-|b|\mbox{\quad if \quad} |a|>|b|,\\[2\jot]
 |b|-|a|\mbox{\quad if \quad} |b|>|a|,
\end{array}\right.
$$
\eqref{eq:1.1.6} and \eqref{eq.1.1.7} imply \eqref{eq.1.1.4}. Replacing
$b$ by $-b$  in \eqref{eq.1.1.4} yields \eqref{eq.1.1.5}, since
$|-b|=|b|$.
-/

-- Theorem statement for |a-b| >= ||a|-|b||
theorem abs_sub_abs_le_abs_sub {a b : ℝ} : |a - b| ≥ ||a| - |b|| := by
  -- The informal proof relies on the triangle inequality: |x+y| <= |x|+|y|.
  -- We'll use the reverse triangle inequality in the form | |x| - |y| | <= |x-y|.

  -- Step 1: Prove |a-b| >= |a|-|b|
  -- The informal proof uses |x| <= |x-y|+|y| from |x| = |(x-y)+y| <= |x-y|+|y|.
  -- Let x = a and y = b. Then |a| <= |a-b| + |b|.
  -- Rearranging gives |a-b| >= |a| - |b|.
  have h1 : |a - b| ≥ |a| - |b| := by
    -- Triangle inequality: |x+y| <= |x|+|y|
    -- Let x = a - b, y = b. Then |(a-b)+b| <= |a-b| + |b|, which is |a| <= |a-b| + |b|.
    -- Rearrange to get |a-b| >= |a| - |b|.
    nth_rewrite 1 [← sub_add_cancel a b] -- Rewrite a as (a-b)+b
    exact le_sub_right_of_add_le (abs_add _ _)

  -- Step 2: Prove |a-b| >= |b|-|a|
  -- Interchanging a and b in the previous inequality: |b-a| >= |b|-|a|.
  -- Since |b-a| = |a-b|, we get |a-b| >= |b|-|a|.
  have h2 : |a - b| ≥ |b| - |a| := by
    rw [abs_sub_comm] -- |b-a| = |a-b|
    -- Apply the same logic as h1 for b and a.
    nth_rewrite 1 [← sub_add_cancel b a]
    exact le_sub_right_of_add_le (abs_add _ _)

  -- Step 3: Combine h1 and h2 to prove |a-b| >= ||a|-|b||.
  -- We know that |x| = max(x, -x).
  -- So, ||a|-|b|| = max(|a|-|b|, -(|a|-|b|)) = max(|a|-|b|, |b|-|a|).
  -- We need to show that |a-b| is greater than or equal to both |a|-|b| and |b|-|a|.
  exact abs_sub_abs_le_abs_sub_of_le h1 h2

-- Theorem statement for |a+b| >= ||a|-|b||
theorem abs_add_abs_le_abs_sub {a b : ℝ} : |a + b| ≥ ||a| - |b|| := by
  -- Replace b by -b in the first theorem: |a-(-b)| >= ||a|-|-b||
  -- This simplifies to |a+b| >= ||a|-|b||, since |-b| = |b|.
  have h_temp := abs_sub_abs_le_abs_sub (b := -b)
  rw [sub_neg_eq_add, abs_neg] at h_temp
  exact h_temp

```lean4
import Mathlib
import Aesop

set_option maxHeartbeats 0

open BigOperators Real Nat Topology Rat Filter

/-
Informal Problem Statement:
If $a$ and $b$ are any two real numbers, then
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.4}
|a-b|\ge\big||a|-|b|\big|
\end{equation}
and
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.5}
|a+b|\ge\big||a|-|b|\big|.
\end{equation}

Informal Proof:
Replacing $a$ by $a-b$ in \eqref{eq:1.1.3} yields
$$
|a|\le|a-b|+|b|,
$$
so
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.6}
|a-b|\ge|a|-|b|.
\end{equation}
Interchanging $a$ and $b$ here yields
$$
|b-a|\ge|b|-|a|,
$$
which is equivalent to
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.7}
|a-b|\ge|b|-|a|,
\end{equation}
since $|b-a|=|a-b|$. Since
$$
\big||a|-|b|\big|=
\left\{\casespace\begin{array}{l} |a|-|b|\mbox{\quad if \quad} |a|>|b|,\\[2\jot]
 |b|-|a|\mbox{\quad if \quad} |b|>|a|,
\end{array}\right.
$$
\eqref{eq:1.1.6} and \eqref{eq.1.1.7} imply \eqref{eq:1.1.4}. Replacing
$b$ by $-b$  in \eqref{eq:1.1.4} yields \eqref{eq:1.1.5}, since
$|-b|=|b|$.
-/

theorem abs_sub_abs_le_abs_sub {a b : ℝ} : |a-b| ≥ ||a|-|b|| := by
  -- The informal proof relies on the triangle inequality: |x+y| <= |x|+|y|.
  -- We'll use the reverse triangle inequality in the form | |x| - |y| | <= |x-y|.

  -- Step 1: Prove |a-b| >= |a|-|b|
  -- The informal proof uses |x| <= |x-y|+|y| from |x| = |(x-y)+y| <= |x-y|+|y|.
  -- Let x = a and y = b. Then |a| <= |a-b| + |b|.
  -- Rearranging gives |a-b| >= |a| - |b|.
  have h1 : |a-b| ≥ |a| - |b| := by
    calc
      |a-b| = |(a - b) + b - b| := by rw [sub_add_cancel]
      _ ≥ |(a - b) + b| - |-b| := by apply abs_abs_sub_le_abs_add
      _ ≥ |a| - |b| := by simp
    -- This is an alternative derivation using algebra:
    -- have : |a| = |(a-b) + b| := by rw [sub_add_cancel]
    -- rw [this]
    -- exact sub_le_abs_of_abs_add (a-b) b

  -- Step 2: Prove |a-b| >= |b|-|a|
  -- Interchanging a and b in the previous inequality: |b-a| >= |b|-|a|.
  -- Since |b-a| = |a-b|, we get |a-b| >= |b|-|a|.
  have h2 : |a-b| ≥ |b| - |a| := by
    rw [abs_sub_comm]
    exact sub_le_abs_of_abs_add (b-a) a

  -- Step 3: Combine h1 and h2 to prove |a-b| >= ||a|-|b||.
  -- We know that ||x|-|y|| is either |x|-|y| (if |x|>=|y|) or |y|-|x| (if |y|>|x|).
  -- So we need to show that |a-b| is greater than or equal to both |a|-|b| and |b|-|a|.
  have h_abs_ge_max : ||a|-|b|| = max (|a|-|b|) (|b|-|a|) := by
    apply abs_eq_max_sub_neg_sub
    -- `abs_eq_max_sub_neg_sub` states |x| = max x (-x)
    -- Here x = |a|-|b|, so we need max (|a|-|b|) (-(|a|-|b|))
    -- -(|a|-|b|) = |b|-|a|.
  rw [h_abs_ge_max]
  exact ge_max h1 h2

theorem abs_add_abs_le_abs_sub {a b : ℝ} : |a+b| ≥ ||a|-|b|| := by
  -- Replace b by -b in the first theorem: |a-(-b)| >= ||a|-|-b||
  -- This simplifies to |a+b| >= ||a|-|b||, since |-b| = |b|.
  convert abs_sub_abs_le_abs_sub (b:= -b)
  -- The left side becomes |a - (-b)| which is |a + b|.
  simp only [sub_neg_eq_add]
  -- The right side becomes ||a|-|-b||. We need to show that |-b| = |b|.
  simp only [abs_neg]

```

theorem abs_sub_abs_le_abs_sub {a b : ℝ} : |a-b| ≥ ||a|-|b|| := by

  -- Let x = a and y = b. Then |a| <= |a-b| + |b|.

  have h1 : |a-b| ≥ |a| - |b| := by
    calc
      |a-b| = |(a - b) + b - b| := by rw [sub_add_cancel]

      _ ≥ |a| - |b| := by simp

    -- rw [this]

  -- Step 2: Prove |a-b| >= |b|-|a|

\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.7}

\end{equation}
since $|b-a|=|a-b|$. Since
$$
\big||a|-|b|\big|=
\left\{\casespace\begin{array}{l} |a|-|b|\mbox{\quad if \quad} |a|>|b|,\\[2\jot]
 |b|-|a|\mbox{\quad if \quad} |b|>|a|,
\end{array}\right.
$$
\eqref{eq:1.1.6} and \eqref{eq.1.1.7} imply \eqref{eq.1.1.4}. Replacing
$b$ by $-b$  in \eqref{eq.1.1.4} yields \eqref{eq.1.1.5}, since
$|-b|=|b|$.

theorem abs_sub_abs_le_abs_sub {a b : ℝ} : |a-b| ≥ | |a|-|b| | := by
  -- The informal proof relies on the triangle inequality: |x+y| <= |x|+|y|.
  -- We'll use the reverse triangle inequality in the form | |x| - |y| | <= |x-y|.

  -- Step 1: Prove |a-b| >= |a|-|b|
  -- The informal proof uses |x| <= |x-y|+|y| from |x| = |(x-y)+y| <= |x-y|+|y|.
  -- Let x = a and y = b. Then |a| <= |a-b| + |b|.
  -- Rearranging gives |a-b| >= |a| - |b|.
  have h1 : |a-b| ≥ |a| - |b| := by
    -- Triangle inequality: |x+y| <= |x|+|y|
    -- Let x = a - b, y = b. Then |(a-b)+b| <= |a-b| + |b|, which is |a| <= |a-b| + |b|.
    -- Rearrange to get |a-b| >= |a| - |b|.
    nth_rewrite 1 [← sub_add_cancel a b] -- Rewrite a as (a-b)+b
    exact le_sub_right_of_add_le (abs_add _ _)

  -- Step 2: Prove |a-b| >= |b|-|a|
  -- Interchanging a and b in the previous inequality: |b-a| >= |b|-|a|.
  -- Since |b-a| = |a-b|, we get |a-b| >= |b|-|a|.
  have h2 : |a-b| ≥ |b| - |a| := by
    rw [abs_sub_comm] -- |b-a| = |a-b|
    -- Apply the same logic as h1 for b and a.
    nth_rewrite 1 [← sub_add_cancel b a]
    exact le_sub_right_of_add_le (abs_add _ _)

  -- Step 3: Combine h1 and h2 to prove |a-b| >= ||a|-|b||.
  -- We know that |x| = max(x, -x).
  -- So, ||a|-|b|| = max(|a|-|b|, -(|a|-|b|)) = max(|a|-|b|, |b|-|a|).
  -- We need to show that |a-b| is greater than or equal to both |a|-|b| and |b|-|a|.
  exact abs_sub_abs_le_abs_sub_of_le h1 h2

theorem abs_add_abs_le_abs_sub {a b : ℝ} : |a+b| ≥ | |a|-|b| | := by
  -- Replace b by -b in the first theorem: |a-(-b)| >= ||a|-|-b||
  -- This simplifies to |a+b| >= ||a|-|b||, since |-b| = |b|.
  convert abs_sub_abs_le_abs_sub (b:= -b) using 1
  -- The left side becomes |a - (-b)| which is |a + b|.
  simp only [sub_neg_eq_add]

  -- This follows from |-b| = |b|.

  -- Step 2: Prove |a-b| >= |b|-|a|
  -- Interchanging a and b in the previous inequality: |b-a| >= |b|-|a|.
  -- Since |b-a| = |a-b|, we get |a-b| >= |b|-|a|.
  have h2 : |a - b| ≥ |b| - |a| := by
    rw [abs_sub_comm] -- |b-a| = |a-b|
    -- Apply the same logic as h1 for b and a.
    nth_rewrite 1 [← sub_add_cancel b a]
    exact le_sub_right_of_add_le (abs_add _ _)

  -- Step 3: Combine h1 and h2 to prove |a-b| >= ||a|-|b||.
  -- We know that |x| = max(x, -x).
  -- So, ||a|-|b|| = max(|a|-|b|, -(|a|-|b|)) = max(|a|-|b|, |b|-|a|).
  -- We need to show that |a-b| is greater than or equal to both |a|-|b| and |b|-|a|.
  exact abs_sub_abs_le_abs_sub_of_le h1 h2

-- Theorem statement for |a+b| >= ||a|-|b||
theorem abs_add_abs_le_abs_sub {a b : ℝ} : |a + b| ≥ ||a| - |b|| := by
  -- Replace b by -b in the first theorem: |a-(-b)| >= ||a|-|-b||
  -- This simplifies to |a+b| >= ||a|-|b||, since |-b| = |b|.
  have h_temp := abs_sub_abs_le_abs_sub (b := -b)
  rw [sub_neg_eq_add, abs_neg] at h_temp
  exact h_temp

import Mathlib
import Aesop

set_option maxHeartbeats 0

open BigOperators Real Nat Topology Rat Filter

/-
Informal Problem Statement:
If $a$ and $b$ are any two real numbers, then
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.4}
|a-b|\ge\big||a|-|b|\big|
\end{equation}
and
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.5}
|a+b|\ge\big||a|-|b|\big|.
\end{equation}

Informal Proof:
Replacing $a$ by $a-b$ in \eqref{eq:1.1.3} yields
$$
|a|\le|a-b|+|b|,
$$
so
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.6}
|a-b|\ge|a|-|b|.
\end{equation}
Interchanging $a$ and $b$ here yields
$$
|b-a|\ge|b|-|a|,
$$
which is equivalent to
\begin{equation} \label{eq:1.1.7}
|a-b|\ge|b|-|a|,
\end{equation}
since $|b-a|=|a-b|$. Since
$$
\big||a|-|b|\big|=
\left\{\casespace\begin{array}{l} |a|-|b|\mbox{\quad if \quad} |a|>|b|,\\[2\jot]
 |b|-|a|\mbox{\quad if \quad} |b|>|a|,
\end{array}\right.
$$
\eqref{eq:1.1.6} and \eqref{eq.1.1.7} imply \eqref{eq.1.1.4}. Replacing
$b$ by $-b$  in \eqref{eq.1.1.4} yields \eqref{eq.1.1.5}, since
$|-b|=|b|$.
-/

-- Theorem statement for |a-b| >= ||a|-|b||
theorem abs_sub_abs_le_abs_sub {a b : ℝ} : |a - b| ≥ ||a| - |b|| := by
  -- The informal proof relies on the triangle inequality: |x+y| <= |x|+|y|.
  -- We'll use the reverse triangle inequality in the form | |x| - |y| | <= |x-y|.

  -- Step 1: Prove |a-b| >= |a|-|b|
  -- The informal proof uses |x| <= |x-y|+|y| from |x| = |(x-y)+y| <= |x-y|+|y|.
  -- Let x = a and y = b. Then |a| <= |a-b| + |b|.
  -- Rearranging gives |a-b| >= |a| - |b|.
  have h1 : |a - b| ≥ |a| - |b| := by
    -- Triangle inequality: |x+y| <= |x|+|y|
    -- Let x = a - b, y = b. Then |(a-b)+b| <= |a-b| + |b|, which is |a| <= |a-b| + |b|.
    -- Rearrange to get |a-b| >= |a| - |b|.
    nth_rewrite 1 [← sub_add_cancel a b] -- Rewrite a as (a-b)+b
    exact le_sub_right_of_add_le (abs_add _ _)

  -- Step 2: Prove |a-b| >= |b|-|a|
  -- Interchanging a and b in the previous inequality: |b-a| >= |b|-|a|.
  -- Since |b-a| = |a-b|, we get |a-b| >= |b|-|a|.
  have h2 : |a - b| ≥ |b| - |a| := by
    rw [abs_sub_comm] -- |b-a| = |a-b|
    -- Apply the same logic as h1 for b and a.
    nth_rewrite 1 [← sub_add_cancel b a]
    exact le_sub_right_of_add_le (abs_add _ _)

  -- Step 3: Combine h1 and h2 to prove |a-b| >= ||a|-|b||.
  -- We know that |x| = max(x, -x).
  -- So, ||a|-|b|| = max(|a|-|b|, -(|a|-|b|)) = max(|a|-|b|, |b|-|a|).
  -- We need to show that |a-b| is greater than or equal to both |a|-|b| and |b|-|a|.
  exact abs_sub_abs_le_abs_sub_of_le h1 h2

-- Theorem statement for |a+b| >= ||a|-|b||
theorem abs_add_abs_le_abs_sub {a b : ℝ} : |a + b| ≥ ||a| - |b|| := by
  -- Replace b by -b in the first theorem: |a-(-b)| >= ||a|-|-b||
  -- This simplifies to |a+b| >= ||a|-|b||, since |-b| = |b|.
  have h_temp := abs_sub_abs_le_abs_sub (b := -b)
  rw [sub_neg_eq_add, abs_neg] at h_temp
  exact h_temp
